column6: Brief Description
Estimated fishery access for boat based and land based fishing based on boat ramps, shoreline access, roads, and steepness of shoreline.
Marine Recreational Fishery Survey (hmrfs) data on the percent of households that fish. This information is used to estimate the need per county.
The number of residents per county. The number of residents and the need is used to get a percentage of the total residents that fish.
The resource was calculated as the total available harvest fish biomass compared to pristine fish biomass.
The condition of coastal habitats measured as the percent of beaches erroding per region.
Beach extent was caluclated from the from ESI GIS layer (Beaches (3,4,5 classifications)). The data units are in km not km2 like other habitats.
The average short-term errosine rate of beaches, estimated at -0.06 m per year.

column3: direct impacts from humans (trampling, recreation, etc)
column6: InVEST recreation model was run statewide at 1 km resolution for the years 2005 - 2014. This model uses publicly visible geotagged photos posted to the photo-sharing website Flickr to calculate the annual average number of photo users per day per grid cell. This is a proxy for direct human impact to nearshore and coastal environments.
The percent of native forests dominated by non-native species.

column3: habitat destruction caused by coastal engineering
column6: Coastal engineering consisted of shoreline armoring structures (e.g., seawalls, revetments, groins, break waters), artificial land (i.e., land fill), and piers.
Dredging was defined as activity involving physically removing substrate with machinery typically to allow for safe passage of vessels.
Benthic structures were defined as manmade features in the offshore environment that disrupt benthic habitat and include moored buoys, channel markers, offshore cables and pipelines.
Represents presence-only of invasive algae species in nearshore waters and mangroves along the shoreline.

column3: land-based sediment export to nearshore water
column6: The pressure on the nearshore from sedimentation. Falinski (2016) customized, parameterized, calibrated, and ran the Integrated Valuation of Ecosystem Services and Tradeoffs (InVEST) model for sediment delivery for each of the eight Main Hawaiian Islands. This model predicts the average annual amount of sediment (tons/yr) exported from each map pixel as a function of land use/land cover, soil characteristics, rainfall, slope, geology, and hydrology.

column3: land-based source of pollution from agriculture and golf courses
column6: The proxy for agricultural and landscaping runoff (nutrients from fertilizers; chemicals like pesticides and herbicides), calculated as the area of agricultural land and golf courses by watershed.

column3: land-based source of pollution from urban runoff
column6: A proxy for nutrient and chemical pollution.
The onsite waste disposal systems (ODSD) as proxy of nitrogen flux to the nearshore water.
The State of Hawaii Division of Aquatic Resources aerial imagery of marine debris from 2015.
column11: Moy, K. et al. Mapping coastal marine debris using aerial imagery and spatial analysis. Mar. Pollut. Bull. doi:https://doi.org/10.1016/j.marpolbul.2017.11.045; Ocean Tipping Points/DLNR-DAR

column6: Ocean acidification pressure scaled using biological thresholds.

The estimated pressure caused on the nearshore environment due to ocean warming. The maximum observed Degree Heating Week (DHW) per pixel was calculated over the time frame of the data (2013-2016). Pixels exceeding 12 DHW were set to the maximum value since it is likely that major coral mortality has occurred those areas.

column3: percent of forest dominated by non-native species
column6: The percent of forest dominated by non-native species.

The coastal population density (withing 25 mi from shore)  as a proxy for intertidal habitat destruction, calculated as resident population per km of shoreline and standardized by maximum regional score.

column6: The modeled reef fish catch from commercial and recreational fishery taking into account shoreline accessibility.
The estimated pressure on the nearshore and coastal areas from sea level rise.
Sea surface temperature anomalies.
To represent the risk of ship groundings and wrecks to coastal waters, the footprint of this ship traffic layer was clipped to 9 m depth.
Ship traffic layer was used as a proxy for ship-based pollution.
The environmental footprint of terrestrial aquaculture facilities.
The modeled UV radiation based on Erythemal UV Irradiance data provided by GES DISC.
